subject: Re: [junit] how to test abstract class
msgSnippet: ... But isn t it a good practice to treat your source code at the same level of your production code?  In fact, I d argue it s more important, in some ways --
messageBody:
On Saturday 25 October 2003 11:56, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> David Corbin wrote:
> > On Friday 24 October 2003 12:59, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > > Siamack wrote:
> > > > This solution may not be ideal but it worked in my case. Inside my
> > > > testcase I implemented a inner class that extends my abstract class
> > > > and provides dummy implementation for abastract method and then I
> > > > used that class to test non-abstract methods. There might be better
> > > > ways. I hope this helps.
> > >
> > > I wouldn't necessarily make it an inner class, but that's what you
> > > need to do: create a dummy implementation of the abstract class and
> > > test that.
> >
> > Do you mean that literally, or do you mean "you'd probably NOT make it a
> > public class"?
>
> I didn't even consider whether public or nonpublic. The odds are that
> such a class would only be in my test source tree, anyway, so it's not
> an issue.

But isn't it a good practice to treat your source code at the same level of
your production code? In fact, I'd argue it's more important, in some ways
-- I think that the number of classes in test-code can easily exceed the
number in production, depending on how tests are structured. This would make
managing visibility more important IMO, just to keep from being overwhelmed.

--
David Corbin <dcorbin@...>
